text: Describe slate, phyllite, schist, and gneiss in terms of texture and grain size.
The parent rock of most hornfels is shale or another clay-rich rock, which has been “baked” by a hot intruding magma body.
Most of these environments occur in the vicinity of plate margins, and several are associated with igneous activity.
Write a description for each of these metamorphic environments: contact metamorphism, hydrothermal metamorphism, subduction zone metamorphism, and regional metamorphism.

We will consider the basic metamorphic environments—contact or thermal metamorphism, hydrothermal metamorphism, burial and subduction zone metamorphism, and regional metamorphism—as well as a few types of metamorphism that generate relatively small quantities of metamorphic rock.
Briefly describe the appearance of the metamorphic rock gneiss and explain how it 4.
Hornfels tends to be gray to black in color and quite hard, and it may display conchoidal fracture.
This graph illustrates the temperatures and pressures typically associated with the major types of metamorphic environments.
Although slate and phyllite resemble each other, how can they be differentiated?
Compare and contrast marble and quartzite.
Metamorphism occurs in many different environments.
In the rock mica schist, what does mica indicate, and what does schist indicate?
Increase in and pressure variable mineral composition.
